messages.content: You are tasked with creating a structured output from the provided user message.

[
  {
    "path": "/{id}",
    "handler": "get_book",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "is_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": true,
    "is_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_restful": true,
    "is_testing": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/",
    "handler": "get_books",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "is_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": true,
    "is_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_restful": true,
    "is_testing": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/search",
    "handler": "search",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "is_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": true,
    "is_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_restful": true,
    "is_testing": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/",
    "handler": "create_book",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "is_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": true,
    "is_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_restful": true,
    "is_testing": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/{id}",
    "handler": "update_book",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "is_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": true,
    "is_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_restful": true,
    "is_testing": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/{id}",
    "handler": "delete_book",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "is_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": true,
    "is_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_restful": true,
    "is_testing": false
  }
]

Explanation:
- I extracted all route declarations present in app/api/v1/book.py that are specified via the Blueprint.route decorator on literal strings. These are the routes bound to the local Blueprint "book".
- Flask route parameter syntax <int:id> is converted to the required form {id} in the output.
- The two occurrences of route("") in the source are literal empty-route strings; in a Flask Blueprint an empty string corresponds to the root path ("/") of the blueprint, so I represented them as "/". They are still marked as extracted from literal strings (is_path_literal: true) because the source used a literal "".
- Each decorated function defined in this file is the handler for its route, and the implementation is present in the same file (implementation_present: true).
- None of the path strings are prefixes only; they are full route patterns as written (is_prefix: false).
- Paths are explicit literal strings in the file (is_path_literal: true) and are not derived from naming conventions (is_derived_from_convention: false).
- These endpoints implement standard CRUD-style operations on a "book" resource, so they are marked as RESTful (is_restful: true).
- None of the endpoints are for testing purposes (is_testing: false).

Notes and assumptions:
- The HTTP methods are not listed in the requested output schema; where multiple functions share the same path (e.g., GET /{id}, PUT /{id}, DELETE /{id}), they are represented as separate entries because they are separate handlers in the file.
- If the blueprint has an external url_prefix when registered elsewhere in the codebase, that prefix is not present here because it is not defined in this file; only the route literals from this file were used.

path.description: The HTTP request path, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}). Set this to null if it cannot be determined.
path.title: Path

handler.description: The function, class, class method, or object that handles the HTTP request. Use exactly "anonymous" to denote an anonymous implementation.
handler.title: Handler

handler_in_same_file.description: Whether the handler's implementation is present in the same source code file, rather than being imported.
handler_in_same_file.title: Handler In Same File

path_is_prefix.description: Whether the path string is a prefix rather than a full path.
path_is_prefix.title: Path Is Prefix

path_from_string_literal.description: Whether the path string is extracted from a literal string defined in the source code.
path_from_string_literal.title: Path From String Literal

path_from_naming_convention.description: Whether the path string is derived from a naming convention supported by the framework.
path_from_naming_convention.title: Path From Naming Convention

is_restful_api.description: Whether the API entry is for a RESTful API, rather than other types of APIs.
is_restful_api.title: Is Restful Api

is_testing_purposes.description: Whether the API entry is intended for testing purposes, such as unit tests or functional tests.
is_testing_purposes.title: Is Testing Purposes

entry.description: List of API entries you found.
entry.title: Entry

message.content:
